text: i'm john harwood with the new york times
in CNBC we're at the offices of the
Democratic National Committee with
Democratic Party Chairman Howard Dean
governor you've taken some flack over
the issue of how much you should be
involved in trying to settle this very
contested Democratic nomination race
what is your view of exactly what your
role is and ought to be in resolving
this well my role is to make sure we
have a fair election between these two
and this is gonna be a very close race
my guess is the loser is going to end up
with forty nine percent of the delegates
so what I have to make sure is that the
person who loses this race feels like
they've been treated fairly that's the
only way on mccain is not a strong
candidate and we ought to be able to
beat him unless we're not unified and so
i got to keep the party together before
we have the nomination process over do
you think anything that's happened so
far in this race has made John McCain a
stronger candidate by weaken your
weakening your potential no not really I
mean the early poll numbers are actually
fairly encouraging we have a small lead
over him but people know some things
about our candidates because they're
fighting each other that they don't know
yet about McCain when we do the testing
McCain's it got a lot of trouble when
people found that find out where he his
position on Iraq that we could be there
for a hundred years no matter what we're
doing there four hundred years they
don't think we should be there four
hundred years when people find out that
he switched his positions on immigration
I'm control on the bush tax cuts they
think he's wishy washy they can't stand
his position on vetoing the President's
veto the children's health care plan
these are swing voters and those are the
voters he can't win without it they're
not going to vote for him how confident
are you that the super delegates who
either one of these candidates is going
to need to get over the finish line
we'll make a decision quickly after the
primaries end in early June and what
will you do to make that happen as you
know governor Bredesen of Tennessee has
talked about some sort of a conclave of
super-delegates well I know I can't make
people do things that aren't in the
rules and the rules say the
super-delegates do it to do what they
want but I don't think it's going to be
any easier to make up your mind if you
wait till the 27th of August than it is
if you
do it around the 27th of June and that
will give our candidates two more months
to campaign that's what they really need
we need to be able to heal the party
after this very vigorous contest for the
nomination so i would like to we're
going to see what happens in the next 10
contests and then I think the unpledged
delegates really need to say who
therefore they need to step up we've
already had about three-fifths of them
say over there for and now I'd like the
other two fifths to say who therefore in
a timely way sometime between now and
say the end of June and if we do that
we'll know who our nominee is and I
think will win how do you confident that
will happen by then I think yeah I think
they're all you be some you know there's
some of their in difficult districts and
they don't want to antagonize one side
or another but I do think at the end of
the day that most of these unpledged
delegates will realize that their jaw
their duty is to their country and their
party and this is not just a about
themselves or about their candidates it
seems clear there will not be revote sin
either michigan and florida there will
be some sort of negotiated solution do
you envision that as a solution
negotiated between the two rival
candidates or is that something that
will get settled after the Democratic
Party has made clear who its nominee
either one could be the case there is a
process for settling it the problem is
you what they're asking to do is change
the rules in the middle of the game both
contestants believe that the nerdy no
delegates awarded in Michigan or Florida
when they went into this primary season
so if you're going to start awarding
delegates you're then going to have to
essentially get the agreement of both
candidates that that's what they want to
do and and some reasonable formula for
doing it both elections were flawed
elections Florida was somewhat flawed
because people didn't campaign there
Michigan was really flawed because it
was only one candidate on the ballot so
they're going to be clearly some
adjustments and there's also it does
have to be a penalty because we don't
want this to go through this in 2012 so
the delegations I think will be seated
but the delegations aren't going to look
exactly like the other delegations will
would you prefer that it be done after
the party has settled on another look I
think I just want it to be done I'd like
to have a convention which includes a
delegation from Michigan and a
delegation from Florida and it doesn't
make a lot of difference to me whether
the nominee is settled or not I think it
makes more sense once we know the
nominee is to do because it'll be easier
but if that's not the case then we'll
have to do it before we know the nominee
is one other element of criticism of
your tenure so far has been fundraising
other party committees have been more
successful visa vie their Republican
counterparts than the DNC s why is that
happening do you think that's a valid
criticism of we've actually I don't
think it's a valid criticism we've
actually out raised the previous DNC by
about twenty percent every single year
but we have an infrastructure the other
other committees Indians the d-triple-c
in the dscc benefit from our
infrastructure they don't have to
maintain any infrastructure other than
the Washington folks they have we have
170 people out in the States we have
voter files that we maintain those help
our senators in our congressmen to we
went out and borrowed 5 million dollars
so for Jim Webb's campaign last time so
we're sort of the piggy bank for the
other two campaigns I don't I think it's
good that they have a lot of cash on
hand but we did not have the kind of
infrastructure you have to have to run a
presidential campaign when I took over
here we do have that now and I think
when we have a nominee will be able to
raise money hand over fist I thought it
was much more important to have a strong
infrastructure if I had to make a choice
than a big wad of cash because at the
end of the day without the
infrastructure you can't win the
presidency now let me ask you about that
infrastructure your state strategy
resembles in some way the way brock
obama's gone about trying to win this
nomination contesting states that aren't
typically thought of this democratic
states how do you respond to the
criticism and it's related to the
criticism hillary clinton's made of
barack obama that competing in states
like Idaho Utah and maybe winning
delegates in a nomination race may be
fine but there's absolutely no chance
the Democrats anytime soon can compete
in a general election in those places
well first of all if you want to have a
long-term strategy for governing the
entire country you've got to compete
everywhere and what the Republicans have
shown over the last 50 years is that you
can win if you're willing to go
everywhere and we frankly are just
taking a page out of what I consider to
be a very successful election machines
which is the Republican National
Committee we're everywhere and we're
starting to win in places like Utah and
we're going to we won the state Senate
Mississippi in Virginia in the last
race in 07 so this idea that we should
only go where we think we can win the
presidency I think has been a Miss an
idea that has served us not very well so
I don't know what I don't think Utah
will be on our swing state list but
Colorado and Nevada will be so we'll New
Mexico and so I you know I'm not going
to comment on a particular campaigns
approach to things but I think you've
got to be everywhere because not only
are you trying to win the presidency you
need congressional seats and senate
seats and governorships and we can win
everywhere we're going to win a Senate
seat for example in Alaska this time
around I think we might win a house see
too well nobody thought that could
happen two years ago governor thanks so
much for joining us my pleasure god
